text: hi everyone
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
sizza album SOS Top Dog entertainment's
queen of r b back with her first
full-length album in five years
following the fan favorite control this
thing over here has been uh long-awaited
the fans have been begging for it it's
finally out and it is a lot no doubt
sizza has spent a lot of her time since
control writing and marinating on ideas
because she hit us with nine more tracks
than she did on her last record and some
of the singles to this thing go back as
far as a couple of years ago but still
that has not stopped this new LP from
feeling new from feeling fresh and
mostly cohesive which is a difficult
feat when you're hitting fans with over
20 tracks and only one of them's a
shorty the song smoking on my X-Pac
which is a hilariously toxic rap cut
where sizza Burns a bunch of mediocre
men and bitter or x's over some
Chipmunks Soul chops we get standout
bars like you hating from nosebleeds I
wish you well it's kind of a crime that
this cut is so short but outside of that
song this is a really robust and
thorough record I can only hope not just
the fans but the casuals can appreciate
just how much magic sizza has handed
over in this album cycle cause no doubt
some people are going to have a harder
time processing this record all the way
through because there's just so much
material here nor is SOS as concise or
Snappy of an album as control which yes
is due in part to its length but also
its production choices because there is
a decent share of strong Lush beats on
this LP Kill Bill for example with its
warm base crisp drums and sparkling
guitar lines gone girls got some strong
bass Parts as well topped with some
classy electric piano keys the murky and
nocturnal trap beats and thick 808s on
low are really great and sizza even
makes an attempt at a pop punk cut as
well on this thing which may be my least
favorite as the drums and the distort
guitars on the chorus are a little
flabby they don't really hit with the
bite I would hope something in this
style would but the tune is there and
the fact that sizza even attempted
something in this vein speaks to the
versatility of the album but yes those
tracks are here but the vast majority of
sos's music is devoted to space and
atmosphere openness there are actually
quite a few tracks on this thing where
the keys and guitars come across almost
shy or afraid of leaving an impression
be it unsure or far or even the chords
that open up the song special where the
highs are cut off to purposefully make
it sound like a kind of Muddy and like
the guitar is coming from another room
taking this kind of Sonic approach on an
album that is this long I could see why
on the surface it may seem like a bad
thing it's going to lead to a more
boring record a grayer record a more
drab record but I think there's a bit of
a trade-off going on here as this change
in instrumental approach does leave more
room for scissors vocals which I think
this time around are are better and
Bolder at least she wants to get that
point across especially on the intro
title track which yeah has a stunning
performance so some very braggadocious
and In Your Face lyrics really seems
like a moment where sizza is not just
trying to convey to the audience the
level of passion she's approaching this
record with but also the place of
desolation she is operating from here
just like the cover kind of shows it
seems like she's stranded in the middle
of nowhere or in a giant body of water
much of the time it feels like her
vocals on this thing are bouncing off of
the far walls and high ceilings of a
Fortress of Solitude so because of the
way things have been switched up
sonically on this LP sizza has really
given herself the challenge of carrying
an album that is a lot more skeletal and
bare which I think she succeeds at doing
case in point the song notice me which
is one of a few tracks on this album
that is so catchy I can imagine it being
accompanied by a much more bubbly
instrumental maybe even something along
the lines of what you may hear in uh
Doja cat style pop crossover but the
vocals on this track are so fiery and
the song is so strong it doesn't really
need it plus I think the simpler
approach here makes the songs that are
sadder more intimate more introspective
hit a lot harder really just like a scud
missile to the fields like the beautiful
guitar and string combo on blind where
scissor sings about being frustrated and
embarrassed about how blind she is to
the better options that she has
romantically in her life again this
instrumental backdrop gives this story
kind of a cinematic feel the feelings of
Desire weigh really heavy because of the
simple instrumental palette on snooze
can't just snooze I miss the moment yeah
just to impotence very strong tune on
that track too I hate you lives up to
its title because of how potent its
emotions are too the rigid beats and
kind of quirky lazy synth lines are an
interesting combo which sets the stage
for a tale of anger towards somebody but
simultaneously you are missing them and
itching for sex with them the verses do
have a lot of mixed feelings but the
chorus pretty much sets it straight and
if you wondered if I hate you [ __ ] you
then there's Open Arms which is a large
powerful sad and self-deprecating Anthem
versus a throws her self-esteem out the
window backed mostly by some very simple
and plunky guitar arpeggios as she cries
out with some very sharp Melodies about
being willing to take this person back
despite all the [ __ ] Travis Scott as
well drops a very focused verse on the
song that I think matches the tone and
theme of the whole thing so good on him
we have more acoustic guitars painting
the backdrop of far where scissors
vocals steal the show once again she
kind of switches things up narratively
singing not about uh running to somebody
but running from and while the Reverb
guitars and beats on too late may fit
the same color palette as much of
everything else here there is a
stylistic shift going on with this track
as this is more of a groovy and sensual
little pop cut with some of the
strongest choruses on the entire record
moving so close we compass
is it bad that Obama then there's
special which is a stunningly tender
moment from Sizzla where she recalls a
time when she was younger and felt
insecure kind of comparing herself to
another woman being upset she doesn't
find herself special in some way but
then we fast forward to a more current
time in her life where she has kind of
reached a special in a sense but now she
has regrets and she's battling different
kinds of insecurities ghost in the
machine with Phoebe Bridgers is a much
better crossover than I thought it would
be the pillowy intention building first
half slides elegantly into the piano
passages that backfibes vocals which
reach a very powerful point of Crescendo
toward the end love language in a lot of
respects is a classic Love on the Rocks
r b narrative the shy and sensual chord
progression fits the bill as well and
there's a lot of edge of your seat
tension going on between the two
characters being sung about on the track
between their desire for each other but
also dishonesty toward each other too as
I said earlier the intro cut is really
fire on the album The outro cut
featuring ODB is really fire as well we
kind of have a an introverse from him
and then from there sizza closes things
out with a lot of swagger on some
melodic and some lines which I'm glad
she kind of ended the album off on a
strong note with some attitude and
confidence considering how raw and
vulnerable and revealing some of the
cuts are in the middle as far as
complaints and low lights I only have a
few I mean one it is a very long record
maybe the Acoustics are leaned on a bit
too hard maybe some of the
instrumentation is a bit too shy Don
Toliver is handily the weakest feature
on the entire record really a non-factor
on the song he appears the pop punk
track again I don't think goes over as
well as it could and shirt while I think
the groove and the CRP r b Vibes are
there the tune just isn't and I think
that is made just very apparent by how
well written a lot of the other songs
and how catchy a lot of the other songs
on the record are in such a way they
could be presented with a myriad of
different instrumentals and they would
still hit but yeah overall this album's
great one of the best I've heard this
year uh sizza killed it I didn't love
every track but it's such a long album
they were bound to be some cuts that I
wasn't super crazy about but despite a
few weak points here and there I think
this record overall is defined by uh
growth by maturity artistically speaking
anyway I know there has been some
comment about uh how sizza is kind of
cycling around a lot of the same
emotions and Vibes around toxicity and
x's and lust which yes is true but I
think she's writing about those themes
in a slightly different way at a
slightly different angle at least enough
to make this record work in its own
right it's still a Powerhouse of passion
great vocal performances and great
songwriting I'm feeling a light too
decent eight on this one transition have
you given this album a listen did you
love it did you hate it what would you
rate it you're the best or the best what
should I review next hit the like if you
